job_title: FMS: General Service Journeyman in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Retirement and health benefits are above industry standard. Some of the best I've seen so far in regards to 403B and health benefits.
Very lax environment in most area of FMS Dept
cons:
Work is very physical. Demanding, repetitive and management doesn't seem to care about the well being of its workers. a lot of guys were out on medical leave or working though their pain to keep their job.

They mostly hire Hispanics and pay them lower wages

Pay is well below industry standard.

No promotions/Upward movement opportunities unless someone randomly retires or gets fired (which rarely happens).

They want workers, not thinkers or people trying to improve their career.

Far as being able to go to school there for free because you are an employee, not so. Smoke and mirrors. You or your spouse, child will have to apply just like any other person trying to attend USC, Very competitive, then IF you/them get in, they use the tuition as taxable income, you can only go to school half time (2 year masters program will take you 4), etc

review_title: Great benefits, less than stellar work environment
job_title: Public Relations in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The benefits are great, including full tuition reimbursement for employees.  In some departments/schools, it is great to work in an academic environment where the process rather than the result is valued.  A lot of very bright professors here and it can be pleasure working with them.  Can be a very creative environment.
cons:
As bright as academics can be, there are many who are ego-maniacs.  The office politics are ridiculous.  Many times staff are caught between the demands of two arrogant intellectuals who think their Harvard degree means they can bulldoze the needs of others.  It is often best to find someone with power to 'protect' you from the infighting, otherwise as has happened many times, you become a casualty of someone's ego. 

If you are not among the senior echelon of the school, your needs are unimportant.  It is an elitist institution and many times it is "who you know" or "where you got your degree" that matters.  I've had colleagues passed up for a promotion because they didn't have a degree or a degree from a "prestigious" university, regardless of the fact that they are more than qualified for the position.

review_title: Good benefits, little opportunity for internal advancement
job_title: Project Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I appreciate the employee benefits, including tuition reimbursement. Healthcare benefits are also better than average. Depending on department, you are surrounded with people who are expert in their field and have a passion for their job. The energy on campus is fun with many lectures and concerts to attend. Professional development opportunities are also available. An effort is made by the administration to foster a real work-life balance.
cons: A major con is that they rarely promote from within, and job titles are salaries are bogged down in bureaucratic mud. The effort to get a raise is so time consuming and almost impossible that people don't have the time or energy to pursue it. Whenever I've gotten a pay raise it's because I've left the position to go to a different school/department. It shouldn't be that way.

job_title: Executive Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The university provides excellent benefits, in particular it's retirement plan. As it is such a large organization, there are many opportunities for movement. There is also a great deal of Trojan pride and spirit which brings everyone together. The campus is lovely and it's great to work in a lively, educational environment. Co-workers have been fantastic and work is generally not too stressful.
cons: The university is very bureaucratic - not particularly suprising as it is such a large institution, but this can  be frustrating. There is also some isolation between schools as each stands alone in terms of budgets, staff, etc. Staff are definitely at the bottom of the totem-pole, well below faculty (who are God-like) and students. This can be incredibly frustrating. Annual pay raises are terrible. The only way to increase your salary is to switch jobs as internal promotions are all but non-existant. This leads to high turnover. The internal workings of the university (esp. databases) are appalling antiquated and there is little coordination of data and information.

job_title: Systems Programmer IV in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Retirement benefits are great, 200% match (at least when I was employed it was that high) to your 401k.
Some interesting work if you are in the right department.
Some great colleagues, co-workers.
Relaxed environment.
cons:
Pay is WAY under industry standard (IT/Information Services).
Politics get in the way of your job about 70% of the time.
Image is more important than "doing the right thing" in ANY situation.
Upper management expects too much from their employees.
HR is completely useless and has no idea how to hire (again, in IT/Information services).
When I was first hired, they told me that as a full-time employee I would be able to take classes as an undergraduate (for free), but then they changed the policy to only allow you to take classes related to the job you held with them. I wanted to learn something new, not just more of what I already know!

review_title: Great benefits if you can handle toxicity and frustration
job_title: Development Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The benefits! Up until COVID, the retirement planning alone was outstanding, they doubled the employees contribution to a Fidelity account. Then getting into health, wellness, and employee training and learning. USC is certainly unmatched.
cons: I have learned that USC is the empire of taking advantage of everything they can without paying it back to their employees. I, somehow, have worked at the university for three years and am still a Fixed-Term, or temporary, employee through a series of contract extensions. Under that, my team has shifted in infinite ways, resulting in me doing double the work I was hired to do, but under my fixed term contract I have no traction to negotiate for higher pay. And I am certainly under the impression that if I attempted to fight for myself in this way, that my contract would be terminated.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Well-known, so it impresses the fools
cons:
They will try to rip you off in every way possible. Get everything in writing. 
 USC is a place for business rather than a place for learning.

review_title: Decent but you can tell organizationally it's on the decline.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Paid sick and vacation days to full time staff. Holiday pay for major holidays and retirement benefits for full time staff. Provides a great opportunity to help mentor a diverse student body. Great counseling center that deals with work life balance issues. Access to insurance options. Generally adequate workstations and a beautiful campus.
cons: Technology implementation is slow in some units and often botched (there are a lot of generational gaps between upper and lower levels). Not much room for advancement. Mistrust and sometimes actual passive aggressive behavior between units and overall culture of short cutting in procedural and administrative decisions. As a result growth opportunity is usually confined to within your unit.

review_title: Dead end, no career pathing, poor higher management, passive, no personnel development
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The benefits are great, beautiful campus, if manager approves, can attend professional development classes and earn certificates in Management, Supervision, Professional Office Administration, Human Resource Management, Project Management, Business Writing, Interpersonal Effectiveness and many software applications such as MS Access I, II, III, Adobe products, MS Project, etc. Usual mix of crowing rooster professors who are put in leadership positions when they should limit themselves to teaching but some outstanding and exciting academic leaders, too. In general, the administrative staff can't hold a candle to those in outside industries where the best are promoted and managers endeavor to develop those with potential.
cons: Too much bickering and passive/aggressive behavior in middle staff management, nasty location though the campus itself is generally safe but not the neighborhood. Low salaries compared to outside industry and very little opportunity to advance. Too many staff managers think they've hired you for life and make little effort to develop or reward outstanding performance.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Benefits from flexibility in hours, off campus since it was under Facilities, everyone has a strong family background/supportive, some perks of coffee and free left over food in kitchens from time to time and staff appreciation lunch events at least a few times a year. They also partake in walk/run events on campus as a company.
cons: Communication with the workload, there will be a lot of paperwork at one point, then some will be scarce so you're more busy pretending to be working rather than actually getting work done because of the social fear of being judged as "lazy" or "playing hooky" when in reality the amount of work available across the board varies. They use an ORACLE system for data entry, and that can be problematic and outdated. Most of their phone calls received aren't filtered properly, so instead of getting real priorities, the lesser ones get in the way.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good brand, campus is lovely.  Great energy on the campus itself.  Wonderful student center with good restaurants.
cons: Many of us on the administrative side are now located away from the campus on the other side of the 101.  We work in what was a warehouse converted into cubicles.  The environment is sterile.  No natural light.  You have no sense of working on a campus.  People on the administrative side are viewed as second class citizens and not seen as foundational to the mission of the University.  Staff are also underpaid and overworked.  There is a lot of burn out.  What is important to leadership is faculty and staff.  It can be a downer.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The  benefits are good, especially the 403b retirement plan where the university doubles the employee contribution.
cons: For the last ten years the average annual pay increases have been around 2 percent.  This doesn't keep pace with inflation or COLA, especially in Los Angeles.  Employee performance reviews have zero bearing on pay increases.  An excellent review often means a 1 percent pay raise.  Bonuses are unheard of.   Senior management is only interested in making themselves look good and line staff are forced to work like dogs to make that happen.  The "Do More With Less" mantra is the main emphasis of management and has been for years.  The result is that staff are forced to work overtime (if they are hourly) or do the job of multiple people if they are salaried.  Finally, there is a clear distinction between how the university treats faculty and how they treat staff.  Faculty are coddled and get the best benefits while staff are at the bottom of the totem pole.

review_title: Not so great and not awful! It's just not bad.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros: You can find smart people in the campus to work with. If anyone likes to live in a warm climate by all menas, USC is a good place.
cons:
The bureaucracy at USC is just horrible. I used to work in east-coast then I moved to USC to do my post-doc. The difference was day and night. It looked like working in eastern Europe or Cuba. For instance, it required a lot of time and paperwork to order one piece of equipment for my lab. Then I realized that it is better that I drive myself, get the equipment and get reimbursed. The system was inefficient with an extreme profit based mentality. In summary, USC is not a great place.
And also, the location of campus is awful It did not look like a university, there was not ANY bookstore around campus!!! there was not any cozy coffee shop around campus. Just shopping malls, food courts etc. I did not have a pleasant experience and happy I am out of there.

review_title: A comfortable environment in which to learn and grow professionally at the start of one's career
job_title: Statistician II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The environment is relaxed in most cases and the ability to flex one's schedule is often available. The benefits package is very strong, especially with regard to retirement, medical, vacation, and tuition reimbursement. For the reasons cited above, most staff/faculty are often in good spirits. As most university environments go, it is one where you will often be mentally stimulated and consistently encouraged by the bright students, staff, and faculty that you get to interact with each day.
cons: You will likely trade salary for those good benefits and flexible working conditions, though the trade off is not an egregious one. In my case, my position was grant funded and I was not the one responsible for writing grants so that sort of uncertainty may not fly with some (n.b. many university staff are funded via fixed term grants). As the university environment is, to type, a highly federated one your experience may vary greatly depending upon what division/department/school/institute you are housed within.

job_title: Student Technology Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Convenience - Most positions you'll be stationed at are on campus and so easily reachable.
Networking - You can meet other STAs, many of whom are from varied fields of study. The Specialists too are pretty interesting individuals you can learn a lot from.
Flexibility - Shifts can be picked up to accommodate your schedule. I find that if you know that you can't make a shift, Specialists are ready to excuse you so long as you provide 24 hours of warning. Usually other STAs will pick up your shift anyways if you send an email or just put shifts up early.
Freedom - I've had situations where I've dropped 3 or 4 of my five shifts during a week because I was busy. There was really no problem.
cons: Pay is basically minimum wage, although that's to be expected of a student job. If you're looking to do homework during the dead time on your shift, choose another on campus job. It's a rule that students shouldn't be doing homework.

review_title: awesome family tuition reimbursement and benefits, mediocre compensation
job_title: Accounting Technician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: most full-time staff get to take winter recess (the work week between christmas and new years day) off (if business needs allow.  if not, they can use 4 days as floating holidays).  the tuition reimbursement benefit offered by this employer is fantastic if you, your spouse, or children are able to take advantage of it (however, the trade-off is the compensation for many jobs is below market value)
cons: BEWARE: if an employment offer is made, REVIEW ALL DETAILS CAREFULLY.  for most full-time hourly staff, a regular work week is 37.5, NOT 40, hours.  this means that if your hourly rate is $20, in a year you would be paid $39,000 NOT $41,600 (this fact is conveniently not mentioned during the candidate screening process).  bonuses aren't offered to full-time hourly staff.

review_title: USC takes good care of their grad students
job_title: Graduate Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: USC takes fairly good care of their grad students, especially recently under the new President (Nikias).  The opportunities to gain teaching experience are fairly ample.  The medical insurance is very good.  The overall employment/HR system - although necessarily highly bureaucratic - is relatively efficient and well run.
cons: The salary is very poor, but that is to be expected as a grad student.  The dental insurance is not great either.  Employment is usually only for 9-10 months a year, so summer months are kind of a struggle.

job_title: Facility Attendant in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-Flexible schedule! It isn't too difficult to find coverage since shifts are only 3 hours.
-Most employees are full-time students. Bosses are understanding of school-related interferences and work with you to keep school as your #1 priority while still being a good employee.
-Very acceptable pay: I think I left at ~$14/hour, which is awesome considering that many days I came in and did my homework all shift.
-If you want to become a manager, just speak to your boss about it. There are many managers and this could help your resume.
-Happy, pleasant work environment! I can remember many times when management did something fun for employees (recognition candy bags, candy on holidays, random days where they'd let us know there were lots of sandwiches in the conference room).
cons:
-Scheduling is sometimes last minute.
-Although I loved this job, it may have set me up better to find a job after school if I took an internship or something related to "what I wanted to do."

review_title: Great educational growth, poor career growth.
job_title: Second Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: A great place to continue your education while you work.
cons: There seems to be slow advancement from within. Don't be surprised if you are treated like the new kid even if you have more education and professional experience then the 30 year secretary.

job_title: Project Administrator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: In general, I love working here.  I work with nice, hardworking people and the culture is generally thoughtful and dedicated to the work.  People are generally helpful and kind; any time I've had a problem, there's always been someone who's been willing to help me out close by.  Many great employee benefits and perks, and being on a beautiful campus certainly doesn't hurt.
cons: In general, I've noticed employees here LOVE to gossip and don't usually veil their comments too well.  You also have to pay for parking which is a decent chunk taken out of a paycheck that isn't the highest.  Things also sometimes take a long time to get through the work pipeline and things can get bogged down with bureaucracy but that's typical university pacing.  Otherwise, it's a really nice place to work.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: They pay TA's decently, even generously, compared to other universities (though this can vary by department, and for ours, the stipend didn't work out to be terribly "comfortable" given the cost of living in LA). Being at a private university does have its pros in terms of funding for grad students, bringing in invited speakers and other cool, intellectual community-building events, etc.
cons:
Working conditions (demands on time, collegiality, etc.), and the extent to which you actually get solid teaching experience (e.g. designing your own syllabus) will depend so much on your department and which profs you're working with. My department wasn't great... felt like grad students were at times treated as an army of worker bees rather than emerging scholars. This was particularly true for the M.A. students, but I think that culture extended across the dept. Can't speak for other depts. 

ALSO: Scandals and administrative corruption, obviously. Being at a private university has its cons, too...

review_title: A Great Place to Work, be sure to choose the right department!
job_title: Graduate Academic Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I was lucky enough to work on the school's Health Science Campus for 11 years in two different departments. I worked in admissions and recruitment. I had incredible bosses and colleagues, extremely hardworking, caring, competent people. For the most part, wonderful students (of course there are always some who are challenging).  It was a job I was happy to go to and felt useful and valued. Fantastic benefits.
cons: I knew some folks who worked in other departments in which politics played a big role in their job dissatisfaction. These folks weren't the complaining types, they were simply working under challenging situations. At any major university, this type of thing can happen. Be sure to carefully vet the department you interview with, learn as much as you can. If you are fortunate, you'll be able to dodge the few departments that are less functional.

review_title: USC is great, although rooted in bureaucracy.
job_title: Communications Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Amazing benefits, great 401(k).
The organization is well-respected and a leader in research and education. USC values education and has a great program in place for employees who wish to advance their education. Many employees attend graduate school, paid for by the institution. Also, children of employees are offered tuition, providing they can get accepted into the school on their own merits.
cons: You can get "lost in the crowd" very easily. Feedback isn't very forthcoming from managers and supervisors. Bureaucracy gets in the way of projects fairly often. I wish the schools would communicate more openly with one another. The competition amongst the many separate schools can sometimes wear you down, especially if you are in a position where you have to work with several different schools on a project.

job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Can be a fun working atmosphere, especially for those who work in the main campus.  There are libraries that staff can utilize as well as various campus events throughout the year.  Vacation time accruals are generous.
cons: Salaries for staff employees are very low.  Senior management is not transparent.  Too many managers out of the office to pursue their "Ed.D" degrees rather than managing the employees who run the university.  Promotional opportunities are limited, and even with a promotion you will still find yourself struggling to make ends meet.

review_title: Working as an administrative assistant at the USC Herman Ostrow School of Dentistry
job_title: Administrative Assistant I in Los Angeles, CA
pros: great benefits and competitive salary for an entry level position, Trojan spirit and pride, friendly co-workers, great working condition and supportive atmosphere. my boss was pleasant to work with and was a great mentor for future career opportunities. even though I was an administrative assistant, I was able to meet many dental professors and get a hands on feel for how hospitals are administrated. I was also given the opportunity to run errands to the Keck School of Medicine of USC. I loved working here; I felt I was part of the Trojan family.
cons: my office was crowded and needed some renovation - expanding the office space to accommodate the staffing, etc

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Trojan Family - the people who work for USC embody the USC Trojan spirit.  "Fight On!" is a rally cry that unites not only the student population, but the workers who devote their life to the university.
cons: Non-communication - Some Directors communicate amongst themselves and expect front-of-line staff to understand directives, but the Directors often do not communicate or solicit feedback from their staff.  In the absence of communication, speculation develops.  Staff members attempt to anticipate the needs of their superiors because they want to show initiative, but some Directors take that as a sign of not following directives.  HELLO, if you would clearly define your vision and give us clear goals, we would do so, gladly.  This is a more recent development and it stems from one Director in particular.

review_title: Better than most Academic Institutions, but still needs some work....
job_title: Researcher in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Reputation. There is a lot of fantastic research going on here. And there are a lot of really smart and knowledgeable people here, but it can be hard to get a hold of them. Most coworkers are generally mellow and cool people, great to socialize with. One thing you can't take away is the chance to to live in Los Angeles, even though USC itself is not in the best of neighborhoods.
cons: The place is not as well organized compared to industry, but still better compared to other academic institutions, such as UCLA ( I used to work there). Pays lower than industry. A lot of the problems here are typical compared to other academic institutions.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: As a student worker, they catered very well to my schedule and were understanding when I made mistakes.  The faciliatated my personal growth by giving me a lot of responsibility, trust, and autonomy.  Many of the skills I learned as a Program Coordinator were marketable and transferable when I was looking for a job to start my career.  In addition, I learned a lot about office dynamics and etiquette.  I moved up in the time I worked there, and everyone was like family to me.  I learned a lor about what it takes to work hard for the community and give.  I learned what it feels like to contribute positively in my work.
cons: The leadership changed when I was there and there was a lot of friction as a result

review_title: It's great working on a college campus
job_title: Social Media Strategist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It's great to work with such bright people who are always curious to learn new things. I've found USC to be open to new ideas and technologies, and the people I work with are very supportive both professionally and personally. It's also fun to work on such a vibrant college campus with such diverse co-workers and students. There's always something new happening. USC also has great benefits.
cons: I wish there were more flexibility re working at home. It would also be nice if USC were in a better neighborhood, but I've never felt in danger and I am so proud of the school for trying to improve conditions and lives in the surrounding areas.

review_title: One of the best jobs I had so far.
job_title: Accounts Payable in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The hours are flexible, benefit include, health (with USC doctors as a choice), dental and vision. The stress is very low and superior are extremely understanding. There is a great sense of community and opportunity to farther your education for free if you decide to. Additionally, your children can get their education for free if you work for 2 years and they get accepted to USC.
cons: So far I have no encountered anything yet and I been working here for 8 months.

review_title: USC Engineering Department for Grad Students looking for Research Assistant Position.
job_title: Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great education, opportunities for development, but need to be strongly driven and must seek for opportunities.  Opportunities don't come to you; you have to go and knock on the door and get them yourself.  Since I work for a professor in engineering department, it is not easy to communicate with him.  But as long as you understand the project well and know what you are doing, then I don't see any problem with the job.  It's a great place to get your education while earning money, so go for it if you can.
cons: Well, I am paid for my tuition while I work, so no complaints there.

review_title: OK campus, not a lot of academic interaction, experience depends on PI and department
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar
pros:
- As a postdoc, there is a lot of flexibility in terms of day-to-day schedule, compared to a 9-5 desk job. 
- USC takes care of their own: if you are a staff, your children can get tuition remission to go to USC for undergrad. Same thing for yourself: if you would like to take a certificate course or earn a Master's, you can get your tuition waived.
cons:
- There is little interaction between the two campuses. Being at the Health Sciences Campus, I feel that I am missing out on the "academic" environment.
- Very little personal growth. The best interest of the PI (at least in my department) is not to promote the growth and career development of the postdoc but to advance their research and get publications.

job_title: Student Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Retirement account even for student workers, close-knit environment with access to mid/upper management that doesn't exist in a lot of organizations
cons: career managers in higher ed are, in general, not in the private sector for a reason. Sometimes those reasons are altruistic and good, sometimes it's because they simply cannot hack it when put under pressure to provide results. This is true at every school and it's true at USC. There is cumbersome bureaucracy and red tape that you would not expect at a private institution.

review_title: Used to be a good place
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: USC has been a good place to work.  People are generally friendly and helpful.  The university has good benefits and educational opportunities.
cons: Under President Nikias the staff are treated terribly.  His disdain for the staff is measurable.  He is all about his ego and money.  The university used to be a nice friendly place to work. Now He has brought in a political environment which has turned working at the university like being in a pool full of hungry sharks.  The turnover rate has increased dramatically due to the stressful nature of the current work environment.  Many long term loyal employees are leaving in droves. Also salaries have not kept up with outside salaries even though tuition has increased every year.

review_title: USC is a fantastic place to work.
job_title: LAN Administrator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: For starters, the benefits are great. Academia is a low pressure enviornment compared to the previous Consulting firm I worked at, where recognition was not based on a "job well done" rather, how many hours you billed clients. I am surrounded by educated and generally kind people.
cons: There are some politics involved, this is probably the case at any workplace. Problems can be easily be avoided by not stepping on peoples toes!

review_title: Good benefits, work/life balance. Serious cultural problems and scandals.
job_title: Project Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It is possible to maintain a solid work/life balance here. Hours are 37.5/week, vacations are generous (including one week in December) and the health benefits are good. They provide on-site childcare, tuition assistance for you, a spouse and children. The environment can be stimulating, with tons of cultural and academic activities, world-class speakers and events.
cons: There is a serious and systemic lapse in ethics from the top down. So many scandals plaguing the university, from sexual abuse to college admission corruption to mismanagement of funds. The emphasis here is about the money -- from donors, from students -- and it has infected the culture here. Faculty treat staff with such disdain and disregard, and becomes a hierarchy that is hard to deal with. Very few opportunities for advancement.

review_title: Public Safety Officer-Dept of Public Safety
job_title: Public Safety Officer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good pay & benefits, including educational opportunities at the University itself. Finally got police status in 2016. High tech equipment,
cons:
New administration micro manages just like prior two admins. They don't utilize your talents to enhance the law enforcement activities they want performed. Lots of politics and playing favorites.  FYI 2012 was not my last yr there, it was not offered as a choice.

I would only recommend working in this campus department if  1. You really need a job. or 
 2.  You have a solid plan to use the educational benefits and move on soon. or  3. You plan to use the position as a stepping stone to a municipal, state or federal law enforcement job.

job_title: Research Technician in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Stable job
Flexible working hours
Good health insurance and benefits
cons:
The salaries are really low 
The management is old style
Superficial morals, ethics and professionalism

job_title: IT Professional in Los Angeles, CA
pros: the benefits are great, as is the sense of family.  trojans are a proud and connected bunch.  there are always exciting things going on on campus, lectures, performances, research, that you can take part in.  usc values education of its employees as well as its students.  it also puts a premium on having a life outside of work.  extra time off during the holidays, decent working hours, etc.
cons: the location isn't great, the food choices stink and parking is expensive.  students are annoying.  annual salary raises are minimum, three percent if you're lucky.

review_title: USC- awesome benefits but direct level management leaves something to be desired.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great benefits- tuition, great retirement package, really good work/life balance
cons: Management is weak. Most people in leadership positions got there simply by "putting in the time" which leads to otherwise nice people with no vision or idea how to lead managing people. I think USC is great for a short time gig, get your free tuition, and then move on somewhere that has a more professional stance toward the way in which managers are hired.

job_title: Graduate School Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It is a good place to work - students are competent but not the best but seem to be well rounded. The university is not in the best area, but the current resurgence of downtown will continually improve the desirability to live and work in the area.
cons: USC is apparently surging up the rankings, which may be more due to directly to intent to "curve-fit" the environment to achieve better rankings than simply making a better environment. Pay is okay...upper management and deans seem more concern with money / rankings that creating the best educational environment. Which may no be different than anywhere else.

review_title: Research Associate in Environmental Health at Keck School of Medicine
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros: As in any academic position, the flexible time schedule is great.  There are definitely opportunities for your own research, and to develop collaboration.   It was also nice to be considered staff with the associated benefits
cons: As in any academic position, the level of your happiness depends a lot on your supervisor.   Also how well you can network with others relies on your supervisor. Mine was awful, which is why I rated the job so low.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Love the campus. Been a grad student for only a few months and have been working as a lab assistant. Even more than when I was a lab assistant at other schools, this position is very independent and takes a lot of self-initiative. To me this is a pro because USC is teaching you how to be disciplined and put your own effort in. No hand holding here.
cons: Trojan time, the way you submit your hours, took a little while to set up, but other than that no real complaints yet. Also, just need to be safe when leaving at night - there have been numerous reports of robberies or attempted robberies in just the few weeks I have been here.

review_title: Job is good. Only wish they'd pay their students on time every time.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: A very satisfying job as a student researcher. I got an opportunity to work on some of the latest technologies relating to battery charging for electric vehicles. My mentor was very understanding and inspired me to go beyond what I thought were my capabilities to innovate.
cons: I did not have a  very good experience with the pay roll department. The job was very satisfying but the payroll staff is very arrogant and they made me work so hard just to get my hard earned money. I was really strapped for cash and they wouldn't just hurry up my paperwork.

job_title: Research Scientist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Access to state-of-the-art instrumentation, opportunity to hear and meet top scientists from the area and abroad, generous holiday leave, decent benefits, competitive salaries, medical center campus is expanding and there is some efforts to be more aggressive in establishing focused research centers, great southern California weather
cons: Expensive area to live, immediate neighbor around can be a bit unsafe, very few places to dine within walking distance, new dean at Keck campus is more concern about bottom line instead of encouraging research, seems the administrative branches of the campus are always in flux leading to redundancy and gaps which can make accessing necessary basic administrative information an extremely frustrating experience

review_title: Fun people and solid networking connections, but not the greatest organizational skills in management.
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There are a lot of great people: coworkers, students, etc. The office is a fun environment for the most part, the office typically gets along, and there are a lot of fun events put on by the staff and the students.
cons: Much of the work is very menial grunt work. Assignments/deliverables are given that take a lot of time and could be better done by the people who are asking for them in the first place.

review_title: While I love USC, the morale of this department, Provost Payroll, is awful.
job_title: Payroll Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: USC offers great benefits, especially if you put in the time- like tuition assistance and retirement plans. It’s a great networking opportunity because you correspond with so many departments at USC, including managers, professors, supervisors etc. There is the ability to internally apply to other USC jobs before they are posted to the public.
cons: The team has some serious attitude problems and a high turnover rate. Frustrations with management, yet colleagues act like angsty teenagers too bothered to do their job and not welcoming to new employees. Training is basically like getting thrown in the ocean to learn how to swim.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Work with the brightest people in the world.  USC also has very great benefits and is the largest private employer in the county of Los Angeles in California.
cons: Great variation in culture from school to school and department to department.  Be sure to understand what you're getting into.

job_title: Graduate Student Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Flexible schedule for student workers, nice environment, excellent learning opportunities, can work full time in summer, great volunteer opportunities, beautiful campus
cons:
Hard to secure a graduate assistantship/ student job in student services, especially if you do not have prior experience. I entered a grad program in education administration looking to gain related work experience, but a majority of campus employers still wanted those with experience, even if the position was unpaid, and you were in a grad program specific to student services. 

I eventually did get a good job in student services. I feel that it should have been an easier rout for those already accepted into a grad program, to get related work experience. This was one of the main reasons I applied to the grad program.

review_title: not so great, no one gets along
job_title: Lab Arts Technician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: stability with benefits. nice building, free air conditioning. I can't think of many Pros. But you don't have to worry that your paycheck will bounce. I had that fear before. There are ample paid holidays. They pay for a complete week off at the end of the year.
cons: low pay makes it hard to live in area, little room for advancement, forced to pay $100/month for parking, little or no recognition for hard work, politics on steroids, management incompetent. The difference between exempt and non-exempt employees is reminiscent of medieval Royalty and serfs.

review_title: on campus student part time job
job_title: Senior Student Operator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: since its an on campus job, hours are pretty flexible, though once scheduled they're super strict. the pay is decent. double pay on holidays is awesome. not too much work. 24x7 maintenance opens up a variety of shift timings to cater to any student's wants
cons: hard work on day shifts tend to go unappreciated.. rules have gotten stricter.. bunch of hypocrites who give you shocks at the end of the semester telling you you haven't been dedicated enough after you've slogged your ass off for them.

job_title: Project Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: As USC is an academic institution, there are plenty of opportunities of personal growth while working. Employees and their offsprings wil get 100% free of tuition.
cons: Since it provides excellent benefits, people want to retire at USC especially they have children. People are keeping their position so there are little career advance opportunities. There are no competitions between employees, which will be pros for someone but good-will competition makes people active and creative.

job_title: Call Center Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It was cool! It pays well for a student job (actually, really well), the hours are flexible week to week, it’s a chill environment and most of us got to do homework throughout shift and still raise money. Very good for students with hectic schedules!!
cons: It’s just not fun to ask for money. I did feel like a mule doing it and like it went against who I was as a person, but follow the structure they give you- and you’ll be fine. Add some enthusiasm to the job and you’ll make it bearable. They really are great people and it is nice to raise money for USC.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Free tuition and good 401K. That's it.
cons: 7.5 hours is considered full time. Parking is expensive, therefore, sometimes I walk 4 blocks to get to work to park for free.  Salaries for staff are very low. Looks like upper management is overpaid. Micromanagement at its finest. Work until your wheels or carpal tunnel fall off type of mentality. Very old system. Be prepared to learn a 1980's system that can take a long time to get use to. System is crap. You rotate as a generalist in different departments just to make sure they can throw you in different areas of need.  Sometimes endup doing things out of your work contract. HR is really good. Talk to them.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Research opportunities, hands on industry projects, strong alumni, international environment, being in a major city in the US, coolness of the school, renowned professors
cons: Old fashioned Professors, horrible area, the pay doesn't match the increasing rents and expenses, party school, charges the students a lot, doesn't spend generously on many aspects related to education, safety, and environment. (I know, the pros and cons sound the same!)

job_title: Cvt in Kecks Corner, CA
pros: Co workers are the most selfish. Working with serious medications on patients heart. Adenosine, lexican, dobutamine with proper training and education. Most of them works there without a license. Just with high school diploma and 3 days training from anonymous trade school that they don't exist anymore. A nuclear stress test is obssrved by a qualified cardiologist. In this facility is just an RN who's just there typing and typing to cover their back in most of the cases. This facility is just famous because the name of the school of medicine. That's all. Talking about the parking you have to park far a way nu the rails of the train. Shuttles usually are delayed. So is natural if you ended up working soaking wet because of the rain plus they break into the cars.
cons: Very low pay. Males workers loves to boolling females worker. A lot of jealousy. Contaminated environment

review_title: Good Campus Job, Experience Depends on Suprevisor
job_title: Student Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great job depending on who your supervisor is. Some supervisors are more flexible than others - allowing you to come in as your schedule allows and will let you take time off (days off) during busy school weeks in order to study.
cons: Not much camaraderie between Student workers and full-time staff. Age gap is noticeable as most of the full time staff is 40+. Experience and enjoyment in the office is totally dependent on who your supervisor is. Some supervisors frown upon interaction even amongst Student Assistants

review_title: Great place to work, but sometimes lacking necessary
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great benefits, clean campus, lots of research resources available for people doing research. Lots of collaboration between groups and departments on research projects.
cons: The bureaucracy is pretty inefficient, and I don't feel that university resources are allocated as well as they should be (lots of money for football buildings, not much money for renovation or upkeep of science buildings, waste disposal department, etc.).  Some staff people are amazing and on top of their game, while others have no clue and make more work for everyone else.

review_title: Overall I enjoy working at USC as well as working with my coworkers.
job_title: Programmer Analyst III in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Relaxed work environment.
Good benefits.
Coworkers are friendly.
Moderately satisfying and challenging work without the pressure to meet rigorous deadlines.
cons:
Don't always get to work on cutting edge technology.
Not quite as challenging work as I would like.
I don't often get to really push myself passed my limits to improve my skills.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: A once in a lifetime opportunity to work on the cutting edge of research in any field you can think of.  I was a biophysicist and worked with world renowned researchers.
cons: It's graduate school, so expect long hours, low pay and lots of frustration, but that's kind of the point.  Complaining about that would be like complaining about push ups in the military.  Most academic researchers do not know how to help you transition into industry positions.

review_title: Positive experience with lots of opportunities to build my own skill set through free units, workshops, events, etc.
job_title: Program Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Working at a university gives you access to an array of educational (obviously) tools and events that help one strengthen one's skill set and widen one's network easily. Exciting events and things to do at all times ... life as if one is a student, only now you're getting paid!
cons: Having to negotiate between different Schools -- different internal systems, bureaucracy, dissolving departments, faculty/co-workers coming and going.

job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Some tuition remission, generous retirement plan.
cons: Job stability isn't what it used to be, and under new leadership, is turning more and more into a corporation. Many staff people are not paid what they are worth, and with this new president putting all focus on poaching research institutions and building new facilities, the perks that used to offset the salary sacrifice for staff are no longer. They have even taken away the subsidy for taking public transportation to work! Plus, it is very difficult to move up.

job_title: Student Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Fantastic people, meaningful work, strong campus community. If you're paired up with a great professor, you can really have a positive impact on the class you're assigned to TA, and its extremely heartening to see students get inspired and excited about a subject matter if you're good at your job.
cons: Departmental politics tend to interfere with progress. Funding can be difficult to acquire for certain projects and classes. Administration seems more interested in construction and campus beautification than bettering opportunities for students and workers.

review_title: Pros and Cons of Research Associate at USC
job_title: Research Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The work benefits are very good and get better over time. Many longtime employees attest to the benefits package.
cons: The pay for many positions in research are very low for Los Angeles. In my case, most (70%) of my take home monthly salary goes directly to rent a modest two bedroom apartment in a modest area. Paying for parking to work is a drag, about $90 per month to park near work...that's if you are lucky enough to get a spot. The surrounding area is very urban (ghetto). Any decent housing options nearby will be astronomical cost.  Therefore, the commute is a everyday struggle.

job_title: Staff
pros: Fellow coworkers create a pleasant environment. The patient population is satisfying to work with. It is an honor to help a cancer patient. You go home more appreciative of what you have. It is a teaching hospital. There's a sense of being able to ask the doctors a question about something you are unsure about and knowing that they are willing to teach you. The residents are more willing to work with the nursing staff than the older doctors you would see at a non teaching institution.
cons: The incompetence of the nurse manager. The break down in communication between middle management and the people on the front line.

job_title: Technical in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Benefits, College environment. Opportunities to be involved with Students. The Students are really great. You get attached to them. They are the cream of the college crops.
cons: For most Staff positions the pay is very low compared to the "Real World". The parking is very expensive. Want to park on campus? it will cost you approx $100/month. The environment for staff is cold corporate. Management can be incompetent, but mostly they are overwhelmed. most employees (staff) not treated well. Recent layoffs due to Nikias not managing the endowment well. USC endowment approx 3 Billion. Stanford:18.7 Billion. President will build buildings while he lays off staff.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: USC is a great place to work in many respects. If you're looking to further your education, the tuition benefit is a big help, especially for undergraduates. Additionally, there is a fair amount of time off and good health benefits. Finally, USC has a distinct "Trojan Spirit." If you're from LA, and a fan of USC, it's a great place to work in that regard.
cons: I get the vibe that other departments aren't quite as fun as mine, and additionally it feels like job hierarchy is fairly important here.

review_title: Low salaries for the work, understaffed
job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: High status university, beautiful campus, some cool people, great weather, many cool things going on, good academic programs, enthusiastic sports program, many different places to work on campus, huge (two campuses - also a con), commitment to being a great university
cons: Low salaries for the work, everyone crying poverty, low status of staff, long hours for limited pay, very understaffed, no access to decision makers, low morale, limited career opportunities, huge, two campuses, no work-life balance (this may depend on the department you work for), staff are an afterthought and not valued,

review_title: USC State Capital Center  It depends on which department you work for...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sacramento, CA
pros: The compensation and benefits are very good.
cons:
Poor top to bottom communication - poor management support from L.A.
University initiatives are more important than staff

job_title: Student Worker in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Some interesting job tasks (research for union negotiations, creating Excel spreadsheets); many great co-workers; occasionally get to run errands in a golf cart or electric car.
cons: Absurdly low minimum-wage pay (they pay the student workers less than the lowest wage on the union workers' pay scale); low recognition from department heads; some menial job tasks (filing, decorating the break room for parties).

job_title: Guest Service Ambassador in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: This job is very easy and laid back. The position name sounds really fancy but it basically is just a parking attendant working at the booth. You help direct guests and sell parking tickets, it is that simple.
cons: The school itself is great, the people are very nice. What sucks about this job is the department. They are very disorganized and very political. it is very depressing to see a department at a major university and yet be so depressed about it. It's hard to move up within the department. If you think this is a step in door, apply to another department. Once you are in transportation, no other department wants you.

review_title: No advancement, salaries do not keep pace with inflation, no incentive for hard work
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Decent retirement plan but other benefits are now about the same as every other US company.  Benefits used to be much better.
cons: At USC, staff are not respected.  Annual salary increases (if there are any) do not keep pace with inflation so the longer you are an employee, the worse off you become.  There are no pathways for advancement because the university has reduced staffing to the bone.  This means that staff have to work harder and harder and receive no reward for their hard work.  It has become a sweatshop and senior management use that to their advantage.  USC has not suffered at all with the down economy. Enrollment is up, contributions to the university are up but the staff share in none of those successes.

job_title: Programmer Analyst III in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very stable environment.  Great retirement benefits.   Great work life balance.  If you have a family and need a stable job, this is the place to be.
cons: Corporate bureaucracy.   Hard to get promotions.  Promotions rarely happen among staff members, to get promoted, one usually need to apply for an opening just like any outside applicants and compete with them.

job_title: Professor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The students are great here. The "University of Spoiled Children" stereotype is totally wrong. Students are professional, engaged, inquisitive, respectful, and, very importantly, very talented. Faculty and staff are extremely nice. It's a happy place to go to work with palm trees.
cons: Crazy bikers and skateboarders diminish the campus environment. The organizational culture feels a bit 1970ish - very strict protocols and hierarchy. All universities have this to a degree, but USC seems to have it even more so.

review_title: Friendly yet unfulfilling and poorly managed,
job_title: Student Technical Lead in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Friendly and team forward atmosphere with a distinct emphasis on customer satisfaction. Some members of the management are exceptional. The job is very communal in nature and it is not uncommon to enjoy interactions with colleagues.
cons: Tends to be disorganized. There is a definite disconnect between the management and workforce. Egos often come before work. Some member of the management detract significantly from the work environment. The job can seem very unrewarding as management views many of its workers as wholly expendable and makes no effort to hide this fact.

review_title: Great Place to Work and Gain Experience
job_title: Associate Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
• Great university that is constantly improving
• High-performing students
• Awesome environment and resources
• Wonderful, collaborative staff
• Good work/life balance
cons:
• Lots of politics and bureaucracy
• Associate VPs more worried about positioning themselves for better roles rather than caring about the actual work of serving students and their departments
• Upper administration doesn't seem to care for or appreciate Student Affairs
• Big university; hard to know what's going on in other areas of campus

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very flexible with schedule,  great staff  for the most part, and nice faculty with the exception of a few.  Having an office is a plus!
cons: Manager is never present during the morning hours of business which leads to staff fending  for themselves and making up their own hours.  Chair brings her kids to work which is a huge liability and is distracting to the workplace.    Unhappy staff will start looking for another job if things don't improve.

review_title: Best Film School in The World
job_title: Adjunct Professor of Cinematic Arts in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It's the best film school in the world in terms of the quality of the students, the experience of the professors, and the connections to the industry.
cons: Salaries for adjunct faculty are low. Adjunct professors are also expected to be working entertainment industry professionals. For many on the faculty, the salary is a tiny fraction of their yearly income. For those to whom the salary matters, it can feel insulting - USC doesn't even pay for parking. An adjunct can expect to pay $15 every time they drive to teach a class. (Just as an example)

job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Lots of flexibility in terms of schedule, good work/life balance. Besides, you can get free units if you are interested in getting a master from USC.
cons: Toxic environment, lack of support in case of harassment (they do have a system implemented, but it is worthless, giving you advice such as you should leave asap as the people above you who are harassing you are too powerful and will not be touched by USC). Highly unfair gender salary gap, lack of transparency, conditions promised that later are not met. Virtually impossible to get a tenure track in certain departments, and no internal promotions, with people retiring still as assistant professor.

review_title: An amazing opportunity to apply in a real world setting, the fundamentals of finance.
job_title: Student Fund Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: As a student, rarely are you able to get a real world application of anything you learn. With the USIF and SIF programs however, the student fund manager is able to actively pitch ideas for investments. This allows the student to come up with their own investment philosophies and convince fellow managers of their thesis. Provides a tangible way to improve not only presentation, but also analytical and technical skills from the research conducted
cons: None. The course itself is highly selective and only 12-15 students a year get to seize the opportunity. If qualified, I highly suggest taking the course.

job_title: Research Associate in East Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Great introduction to academic research
Benefits include a competitive retirement plan and extended education
Health benefits are partly out of pocket upwards of $100+ with Kaiser & USC options
Access to university resources 
On campus cafeteria with employee discount
cons:
The cons are very research group specific. If your group has good leadership with well thought out  research goals the work process will most likely be great. 

Parking was not negotiated into the contract, and as I understand it everyone is liable for paying for the parking. 

Long hours performing experimentation with unknown expectations designed by scientists with a lack of background.

job_title: Facilities Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: This is definitely your typical, easy, student job. The hours are flexible and they work your schedule around your classes and extracurriculars. Plus you get to know a lot of USC students (and athletes) just by seeing at the gym all the time. The people who work there all hang out outside of work regularly.
cons: Extremely frustrating administration. The full-time staff are often accusatory and there is an extreme lack of communication between them and the student workers. No one ever really knows what's going on and the lack of accountability is pretty awful.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The relationships with your residents, staff, and supervisor are the best parts. If you have good relationships with two of these groups, your experience will be enjoyable. Your housing and meal plan are covered as compensation.
cons: Residential Education highly values social justice, but when RAs and residents fight for their beliefs regarding these issues they are not supported by the department. The job is definitely time consuming and isolates many from outside commitments and relationships, particularly on the first month or two on the job.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Professors and Advisors were always very helpful with finding me a class to TA in that would fit my schedule for both years of my Master's degree. All of the classes I TA'd for were very laid back and when I needed to miss a day due to research there was never an issue.
cons: The only real complaint I would have I the payment structure. There were some months where I would not receive my check right away. However, this changed once I set up direct deposit.

job_title: Professor In Business in Los Angeles, CA
pros: successful school that is getting better every year, great benefits for employees especially free tuition for children. Successful sports teams add to the pride and loyalty of the institution and there is a very strong local alumni Trojan network that is very helpful.
cons: crowded city, bad commute, high real estate prices but love working at the university. Can't do much about the environment but the university is working closely with the immediate community to develop strong partnerships.

job_title: Student Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
I can't say enough good things about the Work-Study program, at least in the department where I work.
 Supervisors are extremely lenient when it comes to taking time off for school-related reasons or really for any reason at all.
Great people, decent wages for the amount of work required.

The work-study program really is a godsend.
cons:
-minimal chance of being promoted in any way (but you're a work-study, not even a real employee, honestly)
-raises are few and far between, in my experience

review_title: A neutral experience at the Keck School of Medicine
job_title: Financial Analyst I in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
I would say the work-life balance is good here. I have never ever worked in a place where vacations and day offs are granted so liberally. No one questions you when you decide to take a day off and I have never seen my manager ever deny someone a vacation due to work. USC systems (Kuali and Workday) are also mostly cloud based so it is easy to work from home and many employees take advantage of this. Health insurance is also nice and the 403b retirement contributions are very generous. I don't have children but supposedly tuition is free if your children attend USC. The winter recess is also nice and they give a lot of vacation time and holidays as well. 

The people are also extremely friendly and the environment is very lax with very little pressure. There is also no dress code here and I have seen some of my coworkers (including professors) wear outfits that would get them sent home at some of my former employers. I don't know if this matters to anyone but there are also a lot of physically attractive people here (both students and staff workers).
cons:
Compensation at USC is way below market. I work at Keck and our compensation is far lower than UPC (the main campus) because we do not generate as much revenues as UPC and in my specific department we live and die by research grants. The professors are the rock stars and revenue generators here so if you are a staff member, you are second class. While I mentioned the work-life balance is good here, the workload is incredibly heavy in my specific department since our department is heavily understaffed. My coworkers and I often do not have enough time to finish our work since overtime is not always granted. The systems here are horrific and the technical skills of many of my coworkers are often lacking (although to be fair, it isn't really different from some of the large F500 corporations I worked at). Parking is also extremely expensive here and it is really strange to see some of the star professor freak out about getting a parking ticket.

There isn't a lot of growth opportunities at USC and if you want a large raise or a promotion, you will have to apply for a new job at USC and move out of your position. The pay raises are abysmal and are barely above inflation. A manager at USC once said to me that USC is not a place where you come to start your career but a place where you end your career (although this obviously isn't applicable to faculty/post-docs/research assistants). Performance evaluations are also really haphazard and often do not really reflect the level of achievement. There is also a lot of infighting and politics in my department although it is very passive aggressive. Morale is also low in my department since there were layoffs in the past.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
You got paid when you are still a graduate student.
A great way to know some cool undergraduates.
Enhance your teaching skills and communication skills.
cons: The downside is usually you have to spend over 10 hours in your teaching duty (include discussion session, office hours, grading, etc...) each week. As a graduate student, that is a lot of time. Some students just keeping bugging you with their homework even they haven't think over it in advance.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Fantastic benefits! From paid vacation and sick time, insurances, and savings, no one can beat this.
cons: Being an employee with USC isn't where you go to grow your career. Because the benefits are so spectacular, folks don't leave, meaning there's no opportunity for upward movement. If you're focused on ventures other than your career and are going to work to get a paycheck, this is the place for you!

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great pay and benefits. Some degree of prestige working for a top rated school.
cons: Working in academia is a whole different animal. There is no hustle, no urgency, extremely laid back to the point on wondering how anything gets done (hint: it doesn't). my direct supervisor was all about slowing the work down and bleeding out as much of the grant money as possible. High performers and not encouraged and passive aggressive measures are taken to get in your way. I'm just not worked that way.

review_title: Low Wages, good benefits, At-Will employment means you can be let go anytime
job_title: Staff Member in Los Angeles, CA
pros: College environment, fun smart students. Interesting events if you want to stay after work. Football team, the usc brand gives legitimacy to you.
cons: Low, low wages for most employees. Parking is expensive. Neighborhood is very sketchy. Little room for personal growth. Run like a corporation. Leadership more interested in raising money and building facilities than serving students and appreciating staff. Politics are extreme. More so than any of the 4 corporations I have worked for. Reviews on this site from mostly student workers that are happy to have any job. Take with a grain of salt. I have worked at usc for ten years and desperately want out.

review_title: Great place to gain experience for the future.
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- Allows you to learn many aspects of a certain field
-Allows you to network with many people who have been in academic administration for a long time
-casual work environment
- Great Benefits
cons:
- Hard to advance above people who have been there for years
- Poor communication from managers and senior leadership
-Rely heavily on part- time student workers to tend to administrative work
- Below average Salary

review_title: Fulfilling for certain Student Worker positions
job_title: Web Developer Student Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
I worked for the USC School of Cinematic Art's computing department. The job was fulfilling (real responsibilities), well paid, with flexible hours, great management, and even better networking opportunities.

I worked as a web developer for USC Performance Venues, as well. The community was fun, hours were flexible, and I was respected even as a new hire.
cons:
On Performance Venues: The pay was inadequate for such a leadership position, and the provided infrastructure was outdated, and not a good resume builder.

Most student workers across the university are unmotivated, and spend their shifts sitting at a desk, browsing through Facebook.

review_title: slow moving behemoth with great benefits - Ostrow Dental school is a university wide JOKE
job_title: Systems Administrative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The benefits are stellar, hands down the best around.  salary is usually above average.  Because they employ so many, their health benefits were excellent, and it's a great place to network.  They have a credit union onsite which provides all your banking needs.  They encourage mass transit by having many shuttles that will get you where you need to go.  they discount metrolink monthly passes by $20.
cons:
Trying to get anything done is going to be mired in bureaucracy.  They never fire anyone.  if you are completely inept, and you do deserve to get fired, there' s a small chance you may get laid off.  You would probably have to murder someone to get fired there.  i know that sounds like a pro, but just imagine a company that big with so many inept workers that they cannot or will not remove.  

There is a chasm of difference between how staff and faculty get treated here.  Staff often feel disposable.  Faculty are the rock stars that often get whatever they ask for. Faculty often treat staff like second class citizens.  and this has created a strong Us vs. Them environment.  Since most management were faculty, they're often viewed as already biased towards them. Usually each school's dean has a 10 year term, really two 5 year terms.  So depending when you come to USC, you may be nearing the end of a dean's term.  usually any new dean will clean house and bring in his cronies. 

There's also inter-school politics.  More prominent schools are viewed preferentially, Keck, Cinema, Marshall, and a few others are the big players, the rest are just along for the ride.

job_title: IT Tech in Los Angeles, CA
pros: People were wonderful to work with, students were also. The connections are endless whether it be in LA or all around the world if you know where to look
cons: It does get stressful sometimes. LA traffic does not help that cause either. It is hard to move up and get a raise.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-Great benefits
-Work is fulfilling (students are wonderful!)
cons:
Where to begin? Given my lengthy tenure as a staff person at USC, I could come up with a list a mile long, I'll keep it brief.

-Ridiculously low paying.  Another reviewer said it best-senior management gets paid very well while the employees doing the lions share of the work get paid very, very little. And little to no recognition for their hard work to boot.
-Way too political.  If you're a master at navigating a highly political and white male dominated environment, then this place is for you.  Something I observed quite a bit in my time there was people who basically politicked their every move were successful and made whole careers out of doing nothing.  
-Lack of high-performing individuals. Do you want to work in an environment where everyone will tell you all the reasons why they CAN'T achieve what you're asking them to, just so they can evade any kind of work load or responsibility? Again, then this place is for you.  This is the 9-5 culture at its best.  Those who go above and beyond and expect high-performing teams will not find it here.  There is very little innovation and zero transparency as to how money is being spent.  Questions about resources, raises, or promotions are answered with absolute bs.  
-Managers who know nothing about management.  This includes faculty, who are given management roles over staff people who trump them in actual management experience.  To my knowledge, there is little to no training for managers and no mentorship on how to grow teams and empower people. In short, management overall is a disaster.  If you find a good manager, you've found an anomaly. It's sad.  Very high turnover in most departments for a reason.

job_title: Student Services Advisor I in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- Amazing benefits
   - 10% for your 5% you put into retirement
   - great medical benefits
   - free tuition if you or your kids go to USC
   - etc
- Great coworkers. Everyone is nice and environment much better the corporate type
- Location. Access to everything on around campus and downtown.
cons: People say the location is unsafe, but working here during the day I have not felt unsafe once or even remotely... just a normal city environment during the day

job_title: Admissions Officer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Bookstore discount. Tuition remission. Lowered tuition for your children (if you have any). I would have said the campus itself, but it has been over-built up  and is over crowded now.
cons: Low salaries. Having to pay for your parking. Bad area of the city. Rapes and murders have happened on campus. Rampant, out of control egos of managers and faculty. Imagine the worst, most impossible 5 year olds that you know, then blow them up to age 50+. The usual rotten politics of "academia" runs the place.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Unlike others, I have a great boss, in which I am very fortunate.  I am well respected and my opinion is greatly valued, which can be rare at USC.  I'm at the Health Science location, so we have a smaller sense of community.  I have been able to interact with other staff, faculty and students in a positive manner.  This position is a great stepping stone for me, and I'm trying to learn as much as I can.
cons: I moved here to take this job because it was a better career move for me, but had to take a big pay cut (~48K to ~ 43K).  So, I'm really struggling financially, and living paycheck to paycheck, despite me having a Masters degree.  My boss has promised on getting me a raise (and that's also why I took the position), but its almost been a year and nothing yet.  I now how to look for a 2nd job, because I'm struggling.  I live very basic and I never expected to be so stressed with finances when I accepted this position.  Also, I expected more out of the benefits package.  The retirement is excellent, as USC will match my contribution.  However, the medical is too expensive.  I am paying about $250 a month for just my husband and me to have basic coverage.  The copay's and Rx benefits are also expensive ($25-50 for an office visit, $15+ for an Rx).  I previously came from the University of California system, and their health benefits were much, much better ($15 copay's, $10 Rx).  Also, what I'm finding equally as frustrating is how disjointed and fragmented the USC system is.  No one is accountable here, and no one knows what is going on.  We don't have set departments to contact for assistance (e.g. - human resources, purchases, etc.), and we don't have any employee development courses, etc.  I don't understand how this institution lasted for so long like this.  Even the employee orientation was confusing, and there is no one to speak to for assistance signing up for benefits, answering my questions ,etc.  They just showed these vague, short 2 min youtube clips on medical, dental, vision benefits.  That is not effective, and just lazy.  Again, I really like my boss and the work I'm doing; however, it I cannot receive a pay increase, I find it difficult to stay here much longer.  And it is true what others have said about staff being low on the totem pole in comparison to faculty.  My dept hosted a retreat; however, no staff were allowed to attend.  Only faculty could go.  It showed me that even though my boss values me (who is a faculty member), on the whole, I am not valued to other faculty members within my dept.  Also, there has been a lot of turnover here at the Health Science Campus, which raises red flags with me.  USC is losing a lot of talent to other organizations.  If the cons I listed don't improve soon, I will have to follow suit.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Free ice. Fee filtered water.  Free use of work-out equipment after work hours.  Free internet.  Free Wi-Fi.  Decent benefits with time off.  University closes for winter break between Christmas and New Year.
cons: Lack of institutional control all the way up.  Lack of a training program / Lack of job descriptions / Lack of feedback or expectations / Lack of an Operations Manual / Lack of upward mobility - once you figure out what you should be doing you will be stuck there / Lack of parking - street parking only or you will need to find meter parking $$$

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Working with some of the best minds in the field of research, helping students navigate their educational career and post-graduation,
cons: A culture of protecting faculty and leadership that compromises ethics, a bureaucracy that inhibits productivity and poor leadership

review_title: Mixed feelings. Overall great experience at USC.
job_title: Adjunct in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
As a student: Lots of ambitious, intelligent, creative, and helpful classmates, many of whom have gone on to great things and whose friendships have been priceless both in their own right and for finding work.  
Some professors were excellent. Some were well known and had achieved great things in their fields, but rarely did the two overlap.  
The technical resources at the school are probably unparalleled by any other school, in a good way.
As a professor: Same as above.  + adjunct salaries are respectable plus you get the benefit of having taught at what is possibly the world's most elite cinema school.  Full-time position salaries vary greatly.
cons:
As a student: I wish the well-known professors had served more mentoring type roles, and that the better professors had been given more classes.
While tech resources ran deep, and most faculty were pretty easy to get appointments with, there could have been more opportunities to get monetary resources for films and for people committed to positions other than Director or DP.
Extremely expensive. Extremely.  Easy to ignore while getting loans, but a potential life-ruiner once they're due.
As a teacher: USC is a big big ship, which allows it many of the "pros" listed above, but it also prohibits the school from being nimble when it comes to changes needed in the structure or approach of the program.  Can't have everything at once.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It is a very friendly environment. Working with students is always fun and exciting. The work load is quite low, if it is not finals week. The professors are very helpful and understanding.
cons: The stipend is very low, although it is enough to get by. The work load is very unbalanced. You sit around for couple of weeks and then it gets very busy with homework grading, exam proctoring and grading in the same week.

TA/RA for PhDs only.

Security issues.

review_title: Great benefits and a good opportunity to network with others

review_title: Has its Ups and Downs But a Great Student Job Overall
