job_title: Admissions in Los Angeles, CA

review_title: Excellent place to work, if you find the right school or department
job_title: Lecturer in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Work Study in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Student Housing Customer Service in Los Angeles, CA
pros: As a student looking to make the most of his time, a housing customer service job was near ideal. I was able to do my homework most of the time when there weren't any customers to service.
cons: Management changed (whether personnel-wise or not, I don't know), and began seeing us not as student workers, but just workers. review_title: Good place to be a Teaching Assistant, but plan on getting out and getting a real job ASAP
job_title: Graduate School Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
USC is a beautiful campus, the buildings are climate-controlled, there are plenty of comfortable libraries to work in.  There are a lot of good, free meals on campus at events.  

There is good funding and few teaching assistants, so there is little competition semester to semester.  

There is a Center for Teaching Excellence that sometimes gives good lectures or workshops.  

The university has many star professors who are successful in their fields and work well with graduate students. 

The Health Center is terrific, and primary care is peanuts because office visits are free, and lab costs and prescription drug costs can be applied toward USC's health insurance deductible.  There is a pharmacy on campus that has quick service and submits the insurance claims paperwork for us.
cons:
Many Teaching Assistants share the worst offices, with each other and with old office furniture. They are unpleasant to work in, so we end up borrowing professors' offices or going to the libraries.

Graduate Assistants are considered, by law, and by convenience for universities, as "mentees," not as employees, so we have fewer rights.  For example, at USC we do not have any type of retirement benefits, nor do we contribute to social security, nor do we make enough to begin saving for retirements/houses.  And teaching assistants do not share many of the benefits that regular staff shares.  We can buy, like any student, discount Metrolink passes and trip tickets, but we cannot, like all other staff, have those transportation expenses deducted from our paychecks pre-tax. We can not even access our payroll information like regular staff.  

Our status is highly dependent on our relationships with professors, and a fickle one can really throw a wrench in our career.

job_title: Yoga Instructor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Easy work. Offer some skilled jobs (I was a yoga instructor at the school's gym) that pay better than general labor jobs. Perks each semester when promotions happen.
cons: Bureaucratic set-up. I wasn't paid one pay period and it took 9 months and many email conversations and reminders to receive my pay check.

review_title: Get paid well, don't expect real work if you're a student worker

job_title: Senior Research Associate in Los Angeles, CA

cons:
the salary is not high if you are a staff not a faculty
lack of innovation and challenges, daily repeated work could be a little boring, so not fit those who hold huge ambitious

review_title: Can be a great, stimulating place to work
job_title: Program Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Access to events and programs at world class campus. Smart colleagues and commitment to staying abreast of latest technologies and innovations in various fields.  A real push to excel.
cons: Some programs are understaffed and depend too heavily on interns and student assistants. Some upper level managers are a bit too preoccupied with self promotion and tend to be disconnected from the challenges at ground level in their own programs.

job_title: in La Habra, CA
pros: Overall a great place to work at. Nice faculty and staff members to work with and decent pay as a teaching assistant. The campus is compact which requires minimum amount of traveling when necessary.
cons: The neighborhood of the University is a little dangerous specially in the west and south of the campus. The working load is increasing throughout the years due to the increasing number of undergraduate students.

job_title: Faculty in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I teach a highly technical class, part-time, to students focussed in non-technical areas. I find that the caliber of students at this institution to be better than most. Students are focussed, highly organized, and approach challenging problems with ambition.
cons: While the campus and facilities are mostly new and clean, directly useful resources aren't always readily available. That said, when something is needed, it's usually possible to acquire it. It simply takes the asking and the waiting.

review_title: Good place for PhD students not interested in academic career
job_title: Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: USC provides various master programs and certificate programs that only take weekend time to accomplish. This means that PhD candidates who want to work in industry have the change to expand their knowledge background. The university really offers lots of career options.
cons: USC school of medicine is not strong enough to make their students into high-level scientists.

review_title: Good experience working for a prestigious university.
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Education and 401k benefits are vastly superior to other companies I have worked for. There are a lot of perks working for a university including academic discounts, lots of on campus events, etc..
cons: Salary is a bit lower than other companies I have worked for. You need to pay for parking if you commute to work.

job_title: Graduate Student in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It has been a great learning experience so far. There are lots of great professors and a number of good courses. The campus being small might actually be an advantage since you all buildings are easily accessible. Some of the fellowships are really attractive and makes graduate life so much more better.
cons: Looks like they admit everybody for master's program, which dilutes the program. And lots of construction most of the time which is a bit of a havoc for the students.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Good benefits, decent salary compared to other places, but still not good.
If you come focus on networking and publishing and try to get out of this place after a year.
cons:
Lack of mentorship, at least in the center I work at. USC is trying to change the culture and help postdocs make a career, but that hasn't permeated to the place I am now.
It looks difficult to land a job after the postdoc experience unless your are a real trojan (alumni, not just employee)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Really good academic environment for research. Specially for a person who wants to study spectroscopy in condense matter, department of chemistry is a
Good choice. 
Theses departments are always improving their facilities. There has been several changes happened for last four years. Like clean room facilities introducing new processing devices, Helium recovery system etc.
cons: There's nothing to say much. If someone plans to stay closer to the main campus it would be better to concentrate on Usc housing eventhough it's not expensive than others. Since its LA you can imagine the neighborhood.

job_title: Direct Researcher in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Professors are very good at teaching and giving you ideas. Doing research with them is an excellent trip. We always discuss the projects we do and we can learn a lot of advantage knowledges in this.
cons: The office is very small and we need learn all the new knowledges by ourselves. The price of apartments around is very expensive.

review_title: I was a PhD Student there
job_title: Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Amazing staff members, nice campus, friendly environment, so many different food options on campus, lots of fun on-campus activities
cons: USC needs to invest more on their research facilities, there have been lots of positive efforts recently to improve this issue, but it might take ~5 years for them to to actually work.

job_title: Student Assistant Athletic Trainer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Access to everything. Lots of opportunity to learn. Very big, so that there are lots of athletes to help and learn from. The training staff is very knowledgable about the subject.
cons: Too time consuming. They require you to work over 15 hours per week. This is very demanding for a student to do. Students also often have to work for free.

review_title: Stable Job, difficult to be creative
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: This is one of the most stable places to work with the best fringe benefits I've ever seen. It's easy to move laterally as well.
cons: You must have at least a Masters degree to consider middle management positions. Because it's a stable job, the leadership rarely gives up control. In today's world you need support to learn creative skills. This is not a place where creativity will be rewarded.

job_title: College Adviser in Garden Grove, CA
pros: A lot of independence, and the students are great. I feel I have learned a lot in this job, and I know I can take that with me into my next position.
cons: I am not a huge fan of the data entry, but it is something that must be done. I also know that the management is not always clear with the things they want.

job_title: Network Engineer I in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Good knowledge sharing
Excellent infrastructure
Access to higher management
Good documentation of tasks and payment
Raises are easily given and depend on number of hours worked
cons:
Some of the managers can be rude
Unnecessary bloat in mid level management
Racist mindset of some managers(around 2% of them..my badluck I have such a manager)

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: USC takes care of its employee. As a graduate student, you get two years of stipends where you will not be required to do any teaching. You can just focus on research and graduating.
cons: the location. Its neighborhood is not very safe. During the time I was there, many students have gotten robbed. Some have been murdered. USC has increased its security in the neighborhood in recent years - but still didn't feel safe.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: They pay a decent amount compared to other TA positions at other schools. Also, the professors are pretty accessible. And the Math tutoring lab is a good system.
cons: The neighborhood it's in is obvious bad. Some of the staff could be nicer. The printer was broken so often it was a running joke. University of spoiled children sometimes applied.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: This is a well funded and forward thinking institution that is, for the most part, interested in aligning the goals of the clinician and the school. There are not too many downsides. Great benefits too.
cons: Not the most ideal place to live in Los Angeles if you have kids but a nearly ideal place to live if you're single. East LA is hipster central.

job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Competitive salaries for non-academic positions. Decent benefits. Beautiful campuses in DTLA and Marina del Rey.
cons: Academic environment is particularly cutthroat (even by academic standards). Management have very little power to improve the working environment. Some staff are seen as replaceable. Condescending / disrespectful attitudes from senior to junior staff members are not actively stamped out.

job_title: Work Study in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The faculty and staff are tight knit and always patient (the first time or two) when you need to learn something new. The Technical Theater Laboratory is a particularly friendly place to work. You may be able to do small personal projects with scrap material using the lab equipment when you're off the clock.
cons: Work study positions are all manual labor, but the hours are not long. The theater lab is not air conditioned. Conditions can be loud and dusty/dirty during set construction/disassembly.

review_title: lots to learn, can move to various depts, excellent benefits
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: great benefits: awesome 401k plan, educational incentives, generous time off, variety of things to do on campus, pay is average but it's balanced w/great benefits
cons: experience can vary depending on department and supervisor, may be difficult to move up unless you take on a different position, difficult to get rid of squeaky wheels

review_title: Not much work, but don't be fooled
job_title: Student Technical Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: don't have much work to do, they give you a dollar raise each year you work there
cons: basically give you no training and the supervisors are hard to work with and are abrasive.  They watch you with cameras at all times, so it creates nervous STAs.  Don't be fooled with the "work-Study", you cannot do homework on the job, whatever some supervisors might tell you; others might yell at you for it

job_title: PGY1 Ambulatory Care Resident in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent ambulatory care experience. Supportive directors and preceptors, variety of elective experiences available. Numerous teaching opportunities at USC and option to earn teaching certificate. Excellent work/life balance.
cons: No significant cons, but one improvement that would further benefit residents of this program is having more variety of disease states to manage in clinic. Currently the main disease states encountered are diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The opportunity to work with some real experts in the field you are in is a valuable experience. Most people are lay back, and easy to work with.
cons: Not a topic research university although been advertised as one. If you have a chance to go to a better university, then take it. The professional training is the most important.

job_title: Supplies Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I've learned several communication skills through this job as it required from me to be interactive and a great communicator not only towards my bosses, but amongst customers and vendors helping us sell our product. I also practiced several methods of conducting spreadsheet reports as most of my time consisted of organizing financial expenses, inventory reports, and other tasks.
cons: The cons of course is that I didn't receive much knowledge or practice in my field of expertise (Mechanical Engineering) since it is only a work-study job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good benefits, lovely coworkers in my small team of 5
cons: If you are a young professional and looking to start a career here - run. There is limited to almost no opportunity for growth across departments and schools. The university as a whole is trying to cover how badly they've screwed up with decisions of leadership, but instead of investing in the ground up and incentivizing employees that do great work, they just continue to make committees about every issue while leaving the problem to rot.

review_title: Excellent, I've learned a lot in my field of interest.
job_title: Program Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Convenient - I'm a student so working on campus is great for my lifestyle. I can go to classes on a break from my job.
cons: It's difficult to find parking in the area. Also, I am a student worker and my employment will expire when I graduate.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The location is great coupled with great weather all year round. Also, the infrastructure is superior compared to most other universities but you can expect that from a private university
cons: Living costs in Los Angeles are exorbitant. Moreover the traffic can really unnerve some of the most composed people and is sometimes a nightmare.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The educational benefits and the 401k program, where they double up to your 5% input.
cons: Not much professional growth at all. People who have worked there for a long time never leave. Low pay compared to similar positions at other schools.

review_title: Worked at Health Science Campus. Good benefits including great retirement plan kept me there for over 10 years
job_title: Clinician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Access to great continuing educational opportunties and some great minds (some dead wood also, but great overall).  For some, great career path opportunities if you are a team player.
cons: Politics often over-rules common sense.  Salary low to middling (sometimes subject to research grant limitations).

review_title: Decent, but not someplace you want to get stuck.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Reasonable hours (majority of offices closing at 5pm sharp), good benefits, wonderful university holiday schedule (PTO), enough free cash flow to maintain up-to-date technology/equipment and renovated offices
cons: All faculty and staff pay for parking (terribly expensive parking), work is usually boring/uninteresting, little to nonexistent "company culture", little to no growth... Though varying by department and position, the knowledge and experience you gain is usually not applicable to "bigger and better" companies and positions you may hope to move on to later

job_title: Student Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very nice work place, you get nice people to work with, they would like to help you out whenever you need some help. Also the supervisors are very patient to teach you anything you want to learn.
cons: Low pay rate and large work load. You can get very busy during lunch time when you work at a dining hall.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The department felt well funded.  Had good facilities, access to technology for students.  The administrative folks were all very friendly and helpful.  The pace didn't feel too hectic.
cons: I didn't really have as much managing or supervision over my first term as I would have liked.  While other instructors were friendly, everyone was pretty much all about their own thing and it didn't seem like anyone was particularly invested in helping out a new instructor.

review_title: Good springboard for students transitioning to grad school
job_title: Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Doing cutting edge research in a field where USC's the leader, flexible hours, supportive lab mates, opportunities to get good rec letters
cons: Really old computers (none of the computers in my lab have the same version of SPSS, and we're still running Windows 2000), work not recognized by superiors, minimum wage pay

review_title: Outstanding University, great people, lots of resources
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The organization really aspires to be top-notch, and strives to support both faculty and students to the utmost.  By and large, they succeed.
cons: Wonderful campus in a not so wonderful neighborhood.  Parking is an eternal hassle.  Why do I get the impression they would give up all the academic excellence if they could just secure another national football championship?

job_title: Orientation Programs Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It is great working with new students in a very dynamic office enviroment.  The staff is great and the university is very supportive
cons: As a recent graduate I did not receive any benefits, but that was expected and communicated to me.  I think sometimes it can be frustrating how they choose to promote and can seem overly political.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Sunshine is all year round, which is really nice. Otherwise it's got lots of nice fountains. The university prefers to invest in fountains and 'restaurants' for the students than their people.
cons: Everything else about the university is unadulterated crap. The faculty are largely irrelevant in the research community, or were briefly associated with decent professors and rode on their coat-tails. The students are walking zombie-morons with little to zero initiative and learning ability. TERRIBLE!

review_title: Good place to study, but only an OK place to work
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Stable place to work. The environment is dynamic and if you like working with young and really smart students this is the place for you.
cons: Upper management often makes very paternalistic decisions. Very little input from front line employees. Lots of nepotism and cronyism present in hiring and promotions. Ranks near the bottom in communication. Management focus more on the student experience and not so much on that of their employees.

review_title: one of the best schools in petroleum engineering which provided me with many insights about this issue.\
job_title: Student Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: they have a good community between students. its not that hard to keep up. you have fun things to do in weekends. its in the place to live in the world
cons: its expensive ! you need to pay 1 dollar to print colour pages! its in an unsafe enviroment which make it hard to go wailking by nights if you want to live nearby

job_title: Assistant to IT Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Choose your own hours
Get to work on the same campus you go to school
The administration understands the school/work balance and makes sure to accommodate for it.
cons: At times not a lot to do, can be just sitting around, which is fine if you want the money from the hours but at times can be boring.

review_title: Women's Health at the Engemann Student Health Center
job_title: Women's Health Gynecologist in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
--Point 'n Click EMR is wonderful for continuity of care in a student population
--The edifice is a state-of-the-art facility that became operative Jan 2013
--Adequate time per patient visit (need 30 minutes as USC women are inquisitive)
--Full range of specialists available either in-house or at Keck
--No in-house overnight call (after-hours calls handled by a nurse triage service that has access to an Engemann MD via beeper/telephone if necessary) 
--Superb benefits package
cons: On-campus parking is rather expensive

review_title: A wonderful place to work and evolve yourself.
job_title: Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Benefits are excellent, as is attention to work/life balance for most areas within the university.  Great working hours (unless you're in IT or Facilities), and
cons: Lower salaries than market, but that's to be expected at most HigherEd institutions.  However, it's difficult to keep top talent unless something other than money brings them in.   Also, inertia for established relationships, procedures, etc., is difficult to overcome.

review_title: A good place to work for and will recommend it to friends.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The University of Southern California treats all postdocs as regular staff with full benefits. This is just great for an fresh graduated PhD. And since LA is a high expense city, the pay for a postdoc is pretty decent.
cons: The only thing I did not satisfy was the weather. LA is too dry for me and even I drank a lot of water, I still felt I need more. And almost no rain at all.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: You get free tuition for you and after a few years, your children.  They have staff appreciation days and different events.  The best thing about working for USC is the recognition.  Everyone know the university and they look up to you for working there.
cons: The traffic driving to the University Park Campus is a pain.  The parking is relatively expensive for the staff.  I believe that it's a few hundred per semester.  That's how much I paid.

job_title: Assistant Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent health and education benefits for employee, spouse, and children.  Comfortable campus environment.
cons: Pay is lower in academia in general than in comparable jobs in either the public or private sector.  Downtown Los Angeles location can be difficult in terms of accessibility and surrounding crime.  However, the lower pay is more than offset by benefits, public transit and carpool lanes are easy travel challenges, and crime is almost always off campus rather than on.

review_title: Worked as a student musician teaching assistant. Responsibilities included teaching students and organizing people
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very fun culture to work in. USC is growing and getting better ever single year, so it is exciting. Lots of great things are happening on campus.
cons: Growth felt slow because the university is inundated with new employees. I had no plans on staying for the long term, so I didn't fully invest myself into it.

job_title: Executive Director in Pasadena, CA
pros: Brilliant researchers and physicians in the school and health system are making amazing discoveries and providing great outcomes in the most difficult cases.
cons: Expanding rapidly with many "growing pains." Infrastructure and processes have not kept up with growth. This situation makes it extra challenging to achieve goals and feel a true sense of accomplishment beyond "keeping up."

job_title: Research Programmer in Marina del Rey, CA
pros: Very flexible regarding hours, cool environment. People are super friendly and everybody seems to be happy here. Very good support staff to fix all your time wasting computer faults.
cons: Pay is just OK types. May feel job insecurity bcoz all your salary depends just on the grants ands fundings from other institutions or fed.

job_title: Electrical Engineer Intern in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It is the best research institute in US for Space research and development. ranking wise it is no. five and offers good projects.
cons: Usually have budget problems. They have to look for more sponsor to pay thier non-citizen interns. The work for the same can be extended.

review_title: It was a great opportunity, I'd recommend it to anyone
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I was selected as a research assistant during my masters studies at USC and it was a great opportunity to work with a brilliant professor and some PhD students. I would recommend it to anyone. Pay was great and went directly towards my tuition.
cons: None, although make sure you have enough time to get your studies done and aren't spreading yourself too thin. They will work with your schedule, though.

review_title: Good experience, low salary as I am only a student...
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: As a Ph.D student here, really do not have much to say. However, the experience is really valuable and I have learned a lot here compared with Ph.D experience heard from other friends.
cons: The salary for RA and TA in our department is relatively low compared with other department. What's more, for TA job, we need to be sufferred from high load work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It has a nice environment with many knowledgeable people. It provides people a world class research place to collaborate.  You can enjoy leaving in LA.
cons: It is near downtown LA which is not a good environment. It has a diverse group of researchers so it does not necessarily specialized on a subject.

review_title: My position as a student worker at the Customer Support Center has been overall very positive.
job_title: Student Computer Consultant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Laid-back atmosphere, friendly co-workers. Compensation for student workers is $10/hour, which is quite reasonable.
cons: New hires will have to work a  minimum of 15 hours a week, which is a pretty large time commitment. A job at the CSC can get monotonous, as it is call-center work, but the staff at the CSC are extremely friendly and helpful.

review_title: Great job if you can get it!
job_title: Research Lab Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Beautiful campus, generous vacation time, yearly performance evaluations, great support services like employee counseling for self and family, stipend to use towards public transportation...
cons: On-site parking at USC is hard to get and expensive, the hiring process seems dishonest to me, by this I mean, often times positions will be posted to the general job board when in fact the position has already been slotted for someone else. They should have a separate portal for those types of positions.

job_title: Faculty Support in Los Angeles, CA
pros: USC was a great place to work beautiful campus, great medical and retirement benefits, good work life balance, employees had to pay for parking which was a bit expensive but overall good experience.
cons: You have to pay for your own parking, there are lots all around campus but the ones closest to campus or on campus were expensive. Difficult to get promoted and a lot of red tape when it comes to promotions. But overall like I said it's great working at USC.

review_title: Decent job, not much to it
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Relaxed student atmosphere leads for an interesting work place.  School spirit is high and benefits for staff are a great incentive to stay.
cons: Most employees are student workers so most of the professional work I have to do myself. Work complete is rarely appreciated.

job_title: Research Apprentice in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Independent self driven atmosphere, had the opportunity to design and complete a project based on my availability and willingness to work.
cons: Some conflict with equipment where laboratory work had to be done at other college campuses but overall not a significant problem or barrier to completion of research project.

review_title: Okay pay, expensive benefits, not an institution to be proud of
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There are good people there. You'll meet them one at a time.
cons: Just read the news. Take a job at USC if you want to be ashamed of where you work, or if you just like being the butt of the joke at parties. The highest levels of administration lack integrity. Support/benefits for staff decreased regularly over my time there. Ridiculously expensive benefits are cheaper and better for higher-paid employees.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Everyone gets along well and helps each other.  Chair and manager are easy to talk to.  Each employee is under little supervision and the hours are flexible.
cons: Better communication from upper management is needed.  Simple things like introducing a new staff member to the department would be nice.  No major concerns.

job_title: Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: USC offers good benefits and flexible working hours. They are considerate of family commitments. Lots of experienced people to learn from.
cons: The salaries are modest compared to industry. You also have to pay about $100 per month for parking in a space that is a fifteen minute walk from your office.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I am a student worker and my boss is very understanding if I have to take a day off here or there to study for midterms or for an interview. The work is easy as long as you are on time, organized, and submit projects in a timely manner.
cons: Minimum wage and not that much room for advancement, but that's to be expected as a student worker.

review_title: It was a great experience with some disorganizations
job_title: Course Producer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I learned a lot about my studies while grading and teaching students. It made me more aware to group work and leading a group since I had to be a mentor for groups for their projects.
cons: There was a large number of co-workers and the leadership lacked to give the same direction to all of us. Some of us said one thing, some of us something else because of what we heard from the professors.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Benefits and vacation time were excellent perks for this role. The paid holidays were also a bonus.
cons: Lack of oversight by management. Few opportunities for advancement. Most people who work there have been there since they were students or even before. Not a collaborative environment.

job_title: Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The campus at USC was beautiful. Its surely a steady employer and has pretty good benifits and ability to transfer departments pretty easy.
cons: At times I felt discriminated against for different reasons, intersectionalities. The program administrators were at times disorganized with ultimately wasted a lot of time not only for us students but the PI as well.

job_title: Researcher in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great work environment, Very supportive superiors and huge flexibility to perform various tasks under GEN. Huge potential gain knowledge about the Oil and Gas industry
cons: Low Compensation, sometimes the work becomes repetitive. More industry exposure is required to build a good working clientele relationship. More sponsor and funding is required.

job_title: Dean in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Long established, excellent benefits, high prestige
cons: Paranoia rampant, adverse press, no sense of history, disrespect for role of staff in total university enterprise (as opposed to faculty)

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The pay varies depending on what department you work for, generally I have found employers to be flexible and understanding of a grad student's schedule.
cons: As a grad student, you are delegated fairly menial tasks, have high expectations for low pay. Opportunities for entry into full time employment are minimal.

review_title: Student Technical Assistant for USC ITS: Flexible Hours, Good Pay
job_title: Student Technical Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Flexible hours, friendly co-workers and supervisors, good pay. Worked here for work study program, management will keep you on the team even if your total work study hours get used up. Students have been prompted to center supervisor positions, definite upward mobility.
cons: Was still using command line terminal apps for email and work-shift exchanges during my time there, though it may have updated since then.

review_title: USC is a great place to teach.
job_title: Clinical Associate Professor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It is on a terrific upward trajectory.  It has gone from basically being a top 75 university in the 90's to being what I think is a top 20 university today, and still improving.  The academic quality of the University is improving all the time; the students are better and better.  The energy and momentum is terrific.
cons: Dealing with housing costs and traffic.

job_title: Tour Guide in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It's easy to talk to your managers, and USC allows many opportunities to work in various departments. Transparent with employees about university policies. Able to learn many skills such as public speaking, intercultural communication, and professionalism. Diverse work environment.
cons: Pay can be low when starting, training is a long process, and sometimes management is not always available. Difficult to rise through the ranks to various other positions.

job_title: Laboratory Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The benefits here are excellent, far better than other companies I have worked for. The hours are flexible and the staff is very courteous.
cons: Some of the PI's I work for can be very difficult, but its something you just have to brush off and stick with.

review_title: great place to work, but you need to find a job you like there
job_title: Research Programmer in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Great place and people. 
A sense of community. 
Flexible work style to have work and life balance.
Nice benefit and career development programs.
cons:
Academic life is boring sometimes for people aspiring more.
The neighborhood is not very pleasing.
Some office politics as everywhere else

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: One of the best universities in California. USC has a wide range of research areas, making it easy for graduate students to choose their research interests. As a TA at USC, it's also a valuable experience since the undergraduate students come from different backgrounds.
cons: Sometimes, it is hard to adjust the TA duties with our course schedules and research activities. In this case, we have to ask someone to substitute for us, which is not easy to do.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Even if neigboorhood of the university is not so good, university itself is very nice and cool. They give  great importance to social activities.
cons: I think, they would  allocate more of their money on research and grad students needs. I think they spend to much money for other things like football gyms new buildings!, On the other hand most of the time, paper in the printer at the graduate lounge runs out!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Depends on your lab. But is one of the best places to work your PhD. I had a great time. In my 4th year we got a raise based on increasing cost of living. Little things like that is huge for a graduate student. Great health coverage, gym etc.
cons: Bad area of Los Angeles, even though it is getting better. You have to live a poor man's life hoping that after PhD you can live a better life.

job_title: Assistant Director of Development in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The University provide excellent retirement benefits.  The work environment is very collegial and enjoyable. The university also provide quality resources to employees to succeed.
cons: The University need to provide more educational training/opportunity for professional growth of current employees.  Quite a bit of turn-over in leadership positions and vacant positions are the filled in timely manner.

job_title: Survey and Data Collector/Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: They worked around my class schedule and where super accommodating during exams.  They extended my campus work hours through summer.
cons: The computer equipment was subpar and had problems connecting to the primary network no matter where I was,which was an inconvenience for client and myself.

job_title: Food Service Supervisor in North Hollywood, CA
pros: The University has a large sense of camaraderie and they offer many opportunities for growth, both in the department you are in and in outside departments as well.
cons: Speaking for the department I work in, they run understaffed far too often and for too long which places strain on the remaining teams.

review_title: Horrible, Horrible Experience...Stay Away from USC Keck School of Medicine
job_title: Project Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I hear the UPC or main campus is much better, try that campus and stay away from HSC/Keck School of Medicine at all cost.
cons: I was lied to about my salary, job duties, and everything possibly imaginable about my job.  The last several years was a nightmare, as whole departments were leaving and people are either quitting, leaving or getting laid off.  I was laid off of my job and told that I would be able to recover the loss of salary with another position.  That never happened.  I provided my boss with excellent service & loyalty and never once got any type of raise or any type of support when I was laid off.  On top of that, I was grossly underpaid for my level of education, barely able to make it off of my salary, then laid off with nothing and no support.  Beware of grant funded positions because there is no severance package when you're laid off.  They just tell you within 30 days you have to leave.  Working at USC has been the worse career mistake I ever made.  I wished everyday I was there that I never took that job.  I was recruited for my job and filled with nothing but false truths by boss, and I'm sorry I didn't do the proper employer/organization research prior to taking that job.  I was stuck working in a capacity that I was never trained for and doing work that wasn't remotely close to my educational background.  It was insulting and I had to endure it for years.  Departments are fragmented and disjointed, so its impossible to get assistance with anything or find resources and people to help you do your job.  I worked in academia for years at public schools and I never knew how good I had it there.  USC operates dysfunctionally and I'm really surprised the institution has not been shut down.

review_title: Worst experience in my career. Political, biased, unfair, with little regard to employee moral.
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The benefits package is great. They just raised the medical rates by over 50% though, so not as appealing anymore.
cons:
Easily the worst experience on my professional career. Very unprofessional environment. My first red flag that I should have considered was the interview process. When I was screened, I was told that the salary was wide open, depending on experience. I let them know that I was making a salary in the mid 60k's. When I received a call to be offered the position, I was told "we only have $45,00 budgeted for this position, so what's the least you'll take?" I was working a temp job and needed benefits, so I accepted 5k less than what I was making as a temp. This was definitely a sign of worse things to come. 

There is absolutely no regard for employee moral. No positive feedback is ever given, and there is no employee handbook or firm departmental policies in place, so standards change on the whim of the managers feeling that day. I was forced to miss my university orientation and benefits orientation, which means that I had to sign up for my benefits without knowing what my options were. Managers play favorites, make exceptions for some and not others, and create a hostile environment by pitting employees against other employees less tenured. 

There is also no desire by management to embrace new ideas or best practices. Thinking outside the box is not encouraged, and being proactive is something that is not given any value. I told my manager that I would like to work toward being more proactive instead of reactive, and her response was "Ive been here for 4 years, and it's always been like this, and it will never change." 

Don't be fooled by the name; USC is a great educational institution, but a HORRIBLE place to work.

review_title: Staff are treated poorly at USC.
job_title: Staff Member in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Name recognition.  Branding.  Football.  Campus is quite beautiful.  Educational benefits.  Students are generally polite and thoughtful.
cons:
If you are a faculty member or a researcher, you have a distinct advantage over those classified as "staff."  There is little support provided to staff in terms of equal treatment.  More often than not, faculty are not compelled nor are they required to treat the staff with respect.  The university and educational culture seem to promote and enable this behavior.  As a staff member, you pretty much have to "put up or shut up and leave."  Should you decide to request for mediation or assistance from Human Resources, you are asked to tolerate the faculty's behavior.  

Also, staff who do not perform their jobs are rarely fired.  What would typically result in termination in other fields/industries is tolerated or otherwise looked over at USC.  People can literally fall asleep on the job and not worry about getting fired.

Most of the leadership at individual schools do not have a business background.  Only a few of the schools are run as a business.  The rest serve as pulpits for the Dean(s) to promote their own agenda.  

Once you are hired, you are asked to *pay* for the privilege to park at your workplace.  So you take thousand dollar hit your first day there for parking.

Alot of the administration promote the above described culture.  It's a shame to see them allow other non-faculty staff to be verbally abused by faculty.  Policies are created but are rarely enforced.

Answering phones. But it was work study, so what else do you expect?
Food on and near campus is average at its best.

review_title: Great benefits,Truly an academic institution and high salary for RN's!
job_title: RN Full Time in Los Angeles, CA

cons: Parking is limited,we are provided but you have to wait for shuttle if you don't want to walk,sometimes I take the Metrolink and they offer Free shuttle for UPC and HSC campuses

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Research Associate II in East Los Angeles, CA

Excellent benefits - health, retirement, education, resources, transportation, security, etc.
Great research opportunities 
Supporting staff is very kind and available
Management was always fair and worked with my strengths
cons:
It is very likely that you will have to pay for parking, but many places in Los Angeles do not provide parking for their employees. 

Traffic to and from the campus can be difficult if you commute by car.

job_title: Associate Professor in Los Angeles, CA

cons: The location is too shady. Surroundings are not safe and always prone to all kinds of criminal activities. Also housing is not ideal, especially in medical campus. But glad to hear that USC is building new housing facilities.

review_title: They've been good to me, but flew too high
job_title: Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Smart people, interesting projects, great benefits.
cons: Got to big for their britches and lost their moral compass -- beyond just what made the news, the culture of USC turned into a wallstreet-backed country club.

job_title: Data Analyst Intern in Los Angeles, CA

Good Salary and benefits,
Looks good on the resume,
Unlimited tea/ coffee/ hot chocolate and soda available
Amazing Location to Work (10th Floor of Citibank Plaza with a great view).
cons:
Travel time was a lot,
no interaction between employees,
Very basic tasks given where there was no employee input involved at all.

job_title: Student Worker in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Customer Service Associate in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA

The best reasons to work at the University of Southern California would be the following: 
- Culture
- Benefits
- Management appreciation
- Team celebrations
cons:
Some of the downsides of working at the university of Southern california would be following:
-Career advancement is slow
- Late Promotions

review_title: Great place to work, too bad retention efforts fail

-Positive culture

-Lower pay
-Nothing else, great place!

review_title: A great environment for pursuing research

There are plenty of smart, dedicated researchers here at all experience levels.

There is training available for helping to advance your career, including grant writing and leadership.

Very forward-thinking, particularly in Engineering.

Improved core facilities for biological assays could be better funded and more attuned to research needs.

There can be a lot of layers of bureaucracy in getting grants submitted and signed off.

review_title: PhD Student in Preventive Medicine at USC
job_title: PhD Student in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Human Resources Recruiter in Los Angeles, CA

- Tends to be very high work flow

review_title: A slow, slow death of ones soul

The old adage, "Those that cant teach, is in full display at USC"
Parking is being removed for buildings and not being replaced.
Food choices on campus are being removed and replaced with $12 buffet, overpriced und under performing.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA

Well educated people to work with 
great amenities
very competitive salary 
overall i had a great experience working there

job_title: Student Worker in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA

review_title: A very good university in California
